conclusion: Close stop-cock K; make sure the manometer (U-tube) is partially filled with a suitable, non-volatile liquid (e.g., colored water or oil).
Note the two reference marks on the spherical chamber B, labelled m (upper) and n (lower). The gas in tube A, bell-jar C, and bulb B is initially at atmospheric pressure.
Adjust reservoir D so that the liquid columns in the manometer are level (same height) while the gas level in bulb B coincides with the lower mark n.
Read and record the reservoir height, h₁, relative to some fixed reference.
Lift bell-jar C, place the irregular solid on the platform beneath, and lower the bell-jar to enclose the solid. Make sure no other object changes the internal free volume.

Open stop-cock K briefly to equalize the pressure inside C-A-B with the atmosphere again, then close it. At this moment the trapped gas occupies a larger volume than before (because part of the space is now filled by the solid).
Move reservoir D until the manometer columns are again level (same gas pressure as the earlier reference).
Simultaneously adjust reservoir D so the meniscus in bulb B is once more exactly at the lower index n (the original gas-volume boundary).
Record the new reservoir height, h₂.

premise: The difference in reservoir heights, Δh = h₂ – h₁, represents the extra downward or upward displacement required to keep the gas pressure equal to atmospheric while restoring the same gas volume inside bulb B.
Because the manometer cross-section is uniform and its columns move equally and oppositely, the liquid volume displaced, ΔV_liq, equals the internal cross-sectional area S of one limb times Δh.
The displaced liquid volume equals the decrease in free gas volume within the closed system produced by inserting the solid.
conclusion: Volume of solid, V_solid = ΔV_liq = S Δh

premise: Compute V_solid from the measured Δh and the known cross-sectional area S of the manometer tube.
